status_message: The islands, equidistant between Japan and Korea, have been the subject of dispute between the countries for sevreral decades. Art festivals in Japan have had varying degrees of success. Tokyo Frontline, being held this weekend, is daring to be different.

status_message: Move over musk melons. High-end strawberries, which can retail at ¬•500 a pop, are set to be crowned the new kings of luxury.

status_message: Johannes Braun, the brewmeister behind the Otaru Beer microbrewery in Hokkaido, takes pride in his ales, which have been creating a buzz since the brewery opened 15 years ago. status_message: Although 3-D movies are becoming more common, content for the smaller 3-D screens is still rare. To fill the void, Sony and Fuji TV are rolling out a new TV series exclusively for 3-D televisions. Could this be the start of the ''3-D at home'' revolution?

status_message: Kakizome, writing one's goal using pen and ink, is an age-old tradition in Japan. Calligraphy teacher Rebun Matsuzaki recently took the "bigger is better" approach by using a 2-meter brush to write his goal on paper the size of a small bus.

link_name: Mere mortal waddles on water

status_message: Siberian husky Chaine used to be so domesticated she wouldn't go near puddles, but thanks to a walk-on-the-wild side training program, she's now getting in touch with her outdoor roots.
link_name: Homey husky learns to live a dog's life

status_message: Tokyo has gone to great lengths to make its tap water more drinkable ... so why do people still prefer to buy the stuff bottled?
link_name: Tap water gains for economic not environmental reasons

status_message: So hungry you could eat a horse?  Kato Meat Sushi offers a unique take on cuisine for carnivores, serving raw beef, chicken sushi and, yes, even raw horse meat.
link_name: Unbridle your inner carnivore | Japan Pulse

status_message: "The Cove" will finally be seen in Japan. After local movie theaters cancel screenings of the popular documentary, video-sharing website Nico Nico Doga steps in and offers to stream it online for free to foster public discussion.
link_name: Nico Nico Doga plans to stream 'Cove' for free

status_message: As visa regulations are eased for the Chinese, Japan is preparing to say "Ni hao" to large influx of mainland tourists, making facilities more Chinese-friendly, hiring more interpreter-guides and researching what defines a pleasant stay for the new visitors.
link_name: Tourism revs up for China boom

status_message: In this month's So, What the Heck is That?, Alice Gordenker researches the skin-protective benefits of the freaky full-face sun visors worn by Japanese women. They may look like Darth Vader, but the only "force" they're concerned with is the sun.
link_name: Vader ladies

status_message: Some pregnant women over 35 may resent their mothers' worries and warnings, but experts say that taking extra precautions and asking the right questions is necessary for making pregnancy as safe as possible.
link_name: Don't be afraid to ask questions about giving birth in Japan

status_message: Australian tuna ranchers are fishing for solutions after taking a hit from a series of conservation quotas aimed protecting one of Japan's favorite foods: bluefin tuna.
link_name: Ranchers hope to save tuna

status_message: In this week's Bilingual column, David Morales discusses a time-honored tradition: the value of beating around the bush when asking questions or broaching sensitive subjects.
link_name: The value of seemingly empty Japanese phrases

status_message: Craig Mod, the designer behind "Art Space Tokyo," has learned that one path to publishing success can be found in cultivating online circles of supporters.
link_name: Tokyo-based Mod forges a path for DIY publishing

status_message: Due to lax legislation, child pornography is still a problem in Japan, and child sex abuse investigations are few.  However, the Polaris Project, a nonprofit organization focused on sexual exploitation and human trafficking, is determined to change this by tracking down one predator at a time.
link_name: A light of hope for abused children

status_message: The creation of a synthetic cell last month raised concerns about scientists playing God. In this month's Natural Selections, Rowan Hooper looks at how this breakthrough can challenge commonly held perceptions of the soul and the origins of life itself.
link_name: Synthetic life zaps 'the soul'

status_message: Getting married is a full-time job for actors in the city of Sawara in Ibaraki Prefecture, where tourists flock in June to see reenactments of traditional Japanese weddings amid irises at their peak.
link_name: Brides, boats and blooms

status_message: Known as a "an explorer with a conscience," U.S. Air Force veteran Dave Davenport shed new light on the Battle of Okinawa by collecting artifacts from the 1945 battle, opening a museum and helping to identify the remains of dozens of WWII soldiers.
link_name: Beneath the Battle of Okinawa

status_message: David Elliott has served as a curator in Japan, Istanbul, Stockholm and Oxford.  Now the internationally acclaimed Elliott focuses on the "beauty" within changing perceptions related to culture, time period and distance in his latest project, the biennale of Sydney.
link_name: Closing the distance on David Elliott

status_message: They may be all grown up, but hardcore jazz-punk trio Midori still enjoys scaling speaker boxes, crashing bottles over their heads and making the bold, violent music they're known for.
link_name: Midori grow up, but kids still love 'em

status_message: Although 50 years have passed since demonstrations opposing the U.S.-Japan security treaty in Tokyo, Japan's most violent post-war protest is still fresh in the minds of peace activists like Yuichi Yoshikawa.
link_name: Legacy of 1960 protest movement lives on

status_message: Yes we . . . Kan? Japan's newest prime minister Naoto Kan has claimed his priority is to tackle the rising national debt. But some still remain skeptical about whether he will have the political force to move debates in the right direction.
link_name: Can Kan revive Japan?

status_message: "Give others more fun and more kindness than they expect . . . it's Pac-Man's message," says Toru Iwatani, creator of the "yellow-dot eating" Pac-Man video game. Discover his take on success in this week's Words to Live By.
link_name: Pac-Man creator Toru Iwatani

status_message: Can divorce be a beginning rather than the end?  In a newly concocted ceremony involving ring-smashings and congratulatory speeches made by friends and family, the act of splitting up takes a new meaning.
link_name: Divorcing couples seek solace in ring-smashing ceremonies

status_message: Some Japanese are trying to say sayonara to keigo (formal speech) and focusing  more on ningen kankei (human relations). But for many married couples, convention, both in practice and in language, is still part of being a couple.
link_name: A land of harmoniously secretive married couples

status_message: You don't need to be Buddhist to get a final resting place in Tokyo cemeteries. Your money is good here ‚Äì just bring a lot of it.
link_name: Beyond belief: Graveyard business expands

status_message: Opinions are split on the U.S. military's presence in Futemna, even among foreign residents of Okinawa. In this week's Zeit Gist, find out why the base could be called the 21st century's Pearl Harbor.
link_name: Futenma divides Okinawa's expats

status_message: Although tattooing has roots in ancient Japanese civilization, it became to seen as something barbaric in the late 19th century and later viewed as a mark of gangsters. These days, though, the art of tattooing has begun to draw a younger demographic. But does this mean the tattoo taboo will one day be erased?
